Description: Solid-cast group-figure representing Isis nursing Horus (Harpokrates) in copper alloy; Isis represented in a seated position, her feet on a small base; she holds on her knees Horus with the left arm while presenting her left breast with the right hand to her son; she wears a tripartite wig with uraeus in front; rendering rather schematic; broken small tang beneath base; headdress, most likely Hathoric crown, mostly broken off; relatively well preserved.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Bolton Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Several bronzes representing Isis nursing Horus were discovered in Naukratis. No less than six of them were discovered in the cache of bronzes in a building located in the southern part of the town (on this cache and its content: Petrie 1886, 41-42; Masson 2015). This figure could pertain to this hoard (figure acquired in 1886). This group-figure belongs to the type G12 in the typology of bronzes by K. Weiss (Weiss 2012, 330-331, 822-833, Pl. 56). It became truly popular from the Late Period onwards and one of the most depicted themes in bronze statuary (for example: Grenier 2002, 51-58, pl. VIII-X; Goddio and Fabre 2008, 318-9 no. 178-180; Roeder 1956, § 303-314). Isis nursing is also a theme which is popular in other material in Naukratis (Masson forthcoming b).
